title: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 9: CTAB/Acid Phenol/Silica Membrane Method
title_html: RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Protocol 9: CTAB/Acid Phenol/Silica Membrane Method

source.description: Chill mortar and pestle with liquid nitrogen (fill the mortar carefully with liquid nitrogen, let it evaporate, repeat one more time. Keep the pestle in the mortar when doing this).
Fill the mortar again.
Carefully grind tissue to a powder in liquid Nitrogen.

source.body: Add more nitrogen if needed, but it is important to be careful when you pour the liquid nitrogen. Especially if you are grinding a small amount of tissue in a small sized mortar. The liquid nitrogen tends to “blow” the tissue out of the mortar.

source.description:
Add
to
(depending on the amount of tissue you start with) of prepared extraction buffer on top of the tissue powder and mix in with the pestle.

source.body:
The extraction buffer will freeze because the mortar is still very cold from the liquid NITROGEN.
Do not worry about this – start grinding your next sample.
The tissue/CTAB mix will slowly thaw and at some point you will be able to mix it well using the pestle.

Keep in mind that if you use more extraction buffer you will be working in more 2 ml tubes per sample and that the number of tubes per sample will increase once you reach the Qiagen RNeasy part of the protocol. Thus, there will be a lot of pipetting into the Qiagen spin column. One can do the solvent extraction steps in 15 ml Falcon tubes, but keep in mind that you will still have to pass a significantly larger amount of liquid
through the Qiagen spin column.

source.description: Once thawed and well mixed, pipette or pour the slurry into a 2 ml tube.

source.body:
If the slurry is too thick, cut the tip of the 1 ml pipette tip with a clean razor blade or scissors.
If youstart with a lot of tissue, you might have to rinse the side of the mortar with an additional ml of extraction buffer (or more if needed.)

source.description: Vortex each tube until the tissue is mixed with the buffer.

source.body: To facilitate mixing, you may have to invert the tube on the vortex, and/or heat it briefly in a water bath.

source.description:
Incubate tubes at
for
–
, vortexing briefly (15 seconds) twice during the incubation.

Spin the tubes at maximum speed (>
) for
in a microcentrifuge.

source.body: All of the insoluble matter should form a pellet at the bottom of the tube.

source.description: Pour or pipette the supernatant into a new 2 ml tube.

source.body: Make sure that the total volume ofthe supernatant per tube is ≤ 1 ml. (You will be adding approximately 1:1 volume ratiosin the following steps)

source.description: Add an equal volume (compared to sample) of 24:1chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to each tube.

source.body: We attempted to remove solvent extraction #1 and #2, but doing so lowers the quality and quantity of total RNA in evening primrose (Oenothera).

source.description:
Vortex the tubes for
or until the phases mix and appear cloudy.

Spin the tubes at maximum speed (>
) for
in a microcentrifuge.
Most of the chlorophyll will be dissolved in the lower, organic phase.
Pipette the upper, aqueous phase to a new 2 ml tube.

source.body: Avoid transferring any of the material (usually a white precipitate) from the boundary between the phases.

source.description: Repeat steps 10 to 13 one more time and proceed to step 15.
Add equal volume (compared to the sample) of 5:1 phenol:chlorofom (pH 4.5) to the tubes containing the aqueous phase.

Vortex each tube for
or until the phases mix and appear cloudy.

Spin the tube at maximum speed (>
) for
in a microcentrifuge.
Pipette the upper aqueous phase to a new 2 ml tube, using a disposable pipette.

source.body: Avoid transferring any of the material (usually a white precipitate) from the boundary between the phases.

source.description: Repeat steps 15 to 18 until the interphase is clean (2-3x for most Oenothera) and then proceed to step 20.

source.body: This is likely the most critical step. Do not proceed to 20 until the interphase appears clean.

source.description: Add an equal volume (compared to sample) of 24:1 chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to each tube containing the aqueous phase.

Vortex each tube for
or until the phases mix and appears cloudy.

Spin the tubes at maximum speed (>
) for
in a microcentrifuge.
Pipette the upper, aqueous phase to a new 2 ml tube.

source.body: Avoid transferring any of thematerial (usually a white precipitate) from the boundary between the phases.
At this point the interphase should be relatively clean, especially if you repeated the phenol/chloroform steps to the point where the interphase appeared to be clean.

source.description: Repeat steps 20 to 23 one more time and then proceed to step 25.
Estimate the volume of the aqueous phase based on the markings on the tube.
Estimate the new total volume in the tube.

Pipette the contents of the tube into a Qiagen miniRNA spin column (pink), until the column is almost filled with liquid (≤
).

Cap the tube and spin for
at >
.

source.body: The column should be empty at the endof this spin.

source.description: Discard the flow-through from the collection tube.
Repeat the previous two steps with the same spin column, until all of the liquid in all the tube(s) from the same sample have passed through the column.

source.body: The nucleic acid is now bound to the silica membrane in the spin column.

source.description:

of buffer RW1 to the spin column.

Cap the tube and spin for
at >
.

source.body: The column should be empty at the endof this spin.

source.description: Discard the flow-through from the collection tube.

Apply
of DNase digestion solution to the membrane of the spin column.

of solution RW1 to the spin column.

Cap the tube and spin for

source.body: The column should be empty at the endof this spin.

of solution RPE to the spin column.

source.body: The column should be empty at the end of this spin.

source.description: Discard the flow-through from the collection tube.

of solution RPE to the spin column.

Cap the tube and spin for

source.body: The column should be empty at the endof this spin.

source.description: Discard the flow-through from the collection tube.
Transfer the spin column to a new collection tube.
Transfer the spin column to a new 1.5 ml conical bottom microcentrifuge tube

Add
of RNase-free water onto the column.

Add
–
of tissue into the mortar while the liquid nitrogen is still “bubbling”.
Add at least 0.5 volumes of buffer RLT and mix well by briefly shaking.

source.body: We attempted excluding this step but doing so decreased the RNA yield andquality

source.description: Add 0.5 volumes of 95–100 % ethanol.
Mix by briefly shaking.

source.body: If you hold the tube against the light while mixing, you sometimes see the RNA swirl while it precipitates out.

source.description:
Spin at maximum speed for
to remove remaining liquid from the silica membrane.

Incubate for
to elute at
and spin to to elute.

description:
Implemented by: Henrietta Myburg and Marc Johnson
This protocol is a modification of protocol 8. It was developed after protocol 8 and several commercially available plant RNA isolation kits failed to produce a sufficient yield and quality of RNA from Oenothera spp. (Onagraceae) for next-generation sequencing. Oenothera are rich in polysaccharides, oils, flavonoids and complex ellagitannins that likely interfere with isolation.
We suspect that this protocol will be most useful for species and tissues with complex secondary
chemistry and rich in oils (e.g. some Rosaceae and Pinaceae).
The most important modifications to this protocol versus Protocol 8 is the use of less plant tissue, more extraction buffer, and repeating solvent extractions until the interphase is clean of debris. The protocol is regrettably longer and more involved than Protocol 8. We attempted to remove or reduce the replication of the solvent extractions steps without success (i.e. yield and quality are always decreased in Oenothera when any steps are removed).
This protocol is part of a collection of eighteen protocols used to isolate total RNA from plant tissue. (RNA Isolation from Plant Tissue Collection: https://www.protocols.io/view/rna-isolation-from-plant-tissue-439gyr6)
